net.cloud.gfx.elements.modal

Class InputDialog

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.cloud.gfx.elements.AbstractElement
      • net.cloud.gfx.elements.PriorityContainer
        • net.cloud.gfx.elements.Interface
          • net.cloud.gfx.elements.modal.AbstractModalDialog
            • net.cloud.gfx.elements.modal.InputDialog
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Container<Element>, Element, Focusable

    public class InputDialog
extends AbstractModalDialog
    An input dialog is a basic yet powerful way of getting user input. It simply gets it in the form of a string. There are options to confirm the input and cancel the input. Canceling the input will yield a null result, although InputDialog.CANCELED can be used instead for clarity. The empty string will be the empty string. An InputValidator may also be provided. This allows the dialog to validate input before returning it, and also display a message as to what is wrong with the input. This is more effective than looping in using code as the dialog will stay in place and it's all handled for us :)

    • Constructor Detail

      • InputDialog

        public InputDialog(java.lang.String prompt,
                   int x,
                   int y,
                   int width,
                   int height)
        Minimal constructor. Create a dialog at the given location that will be the given size. There will be two buttons on it, for confirmation or cancel, as well as a prompt message asking them for input. Sandwiched between these will be a text field for entering input.
        Parameters:
        prompt - What you're asking the user to input
        x - X location
        y - Y location
        width - Width of the interface
        height - Height of the interface

      • InputDialog

        public InputDialog(java.lang.String prompt,
                   int x,
                   int y,
                   int width,
                   int height,
                   InputValidator<java.lang.String> validator)
        Create a dialog at the given location that will be the given size. There will be two buttons on it, for confirmation or cancel, as well as a prompt message asking them for input. Sandwiched between these will be a text field for entering input. There will be an InputValidator making sure input is okay before calling any outside listeners
        Parameters:
        prompt - What you're asking the user to input
        x - X location
        y - Y location
        width - Width of the interface
        height - Height of the interface
        validator - The InputValidator that will check to make sure the given input is okay before confirming it out

    • Method Detail

      • getInputText

        public java.lang.String getInputText()
        Obtain the current text in the input field of this dialog. At no point should it be null, it will at least be the empty string.
        Returns:
        The current text in the input field

      • setConfirmListener

        public void setConfirmListener(java.lang.Runnable listener)
        Provide a listener to this dialog that will be informed when the 'okay' button is pressed. There are no return values or parameters, so a Runnable is fitting. Null may be provided to remove an existing listener
        Parameters:
        listener - Action to take when the 'okay' button is clicked

      • setCancelListener

        public void setCancelListener(java.lang.Runnable listener)
        Provide a listener to this dialog that will be informed when the 'cancel' button is pressed. There are no return values or parameters, so a Runnable is fitting. Null may be provided to remove an existing listener
        Parameters:
        listener - Action to take when the 'cancel' button is clicked

      • setInputValidator

        public void setInputValidator(InputValidator<java.lang.String> validator)
        Provide an InputValidator to this dialog. The dialog will check with the validator before confirming whatever input is present. If it is invalid, the message is displayed in red on the dialog. Setting this null will remove any existing validator
        Parameters:
        validator - The validator to check user input with

      • confirmButtonAction

        private void confirmButtonAction(Button b)
        When the confirm button is clicked, this is called. It'll relay the action to whoever is listening outside of this dialog. Functional programming is so cool!
        Parameters:
        b - The button that was clicked

      • cancelButtonAction

        private void cancelButtonAction(Button b)
        When the cancel button is clicked, this is called. It'll relay the action to whoever is listening outside of this dialog. Functional programming is so cool!
        Parameters:
        b - The button that was clicked

      • textFieldAction

        private void textFieldAction(TextField field,
                             java.lang.String text)
        When the text field is acted on (has its text entered) it'll relay that action to this method, which will in turn relay it to whoever is listening for confirmation on this dialog.
        Parameters:
        field - The text field
        text - The text in the field
